ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Instructive material over grammar points and the dialogue, followed by conversation or recitation to practice pronunciation.
We had a combination of live virtual lectures as well as a weekly live virtual one on one TA session.
I learned best when in the main Zoom classroom - the teacher called on everyone for questions, and I learned from other people's answers and corrections
There were weekly mandatory Tutorial sessions with a TF.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: chinese
Learned to speak, write, and read Chinese!
I learned a lot about how to read and write Chinese. I also became more familiarized with Chinese grammar.

I learned 200-300 characters (read and write), grammar points, and better pronunciation. I'm much more comfortable speaking, and it's so exciting to be able to read subtitles or text messages in Chinese now!

I definitely learned how to structure my time better with this course as the course load was pretty heavy with quizzes and assignments each day and scheduling time in to learn new characters every day.
Chinese speaking/writing

I learned approximately 500 hanzi characters, many different grammatical structures/vocab, and correct pronunciation and interpretation of pinyin. I also greatly developed my reading and writing level from nonexistent to an impressive level where I was able to write my grandparents letters completely in hanzi, read basic short stories and passages, and communicate with our professor via email in hanzi (with a little help from google translate).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of the course are that it is a very rigorous course that allows you to learn a lot in very short time. The class is also very engaging!

It is very well suited for heritage speakers because there is a greater emphasis on writing and reading as well as conversation rather than specific grammar points. However, I had a bit of trouble knowing the latter vocabulary since they were more specific than the types of conversations me and my parents would have, but I could catch up since we worked on it every day.

Strengths: high participation, rigorous workload
Could be improved with faster feedback on homework? I think I found myself making the same mistakes more than once before corrections came back and I realized what I was doing wrong. I understand that there is a lot of homework to grade though

A major strength was the extrememly organized structure of the course and definitely the amazing professor I had. Professor Chan was extremely friendly and caring as a professor and her enthusiasm carried the class all the way to the end. She was always keeping the class engaged and attentive. A weakness of the course is also a necessity of it - learning Chinese is a very intensive and process and both consumes large amounts of time and mental capacity. My stress peaked around 2 months in when I still was getting used to the heavy workload of having daily homework assignments, journals, and new-vocab drilling which equated to around 2-3 hours a night. After then, though, I got into a better flow of doing my daily work. It was a bit of a chore to stay so on-top of things because it was a never-ending marathon, and I definitely felt my motivation waning near the end, but it was worth it. A minor weakness would be that professor Chan isn't the most timely with getting assignments in - it was mostly due to technically difficulties with getting adjusted to doing the whole class online though, and we usually would get grades back at most a week after the fact.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I don't think anything could have been improved. Overall, everything was very engaging and was challenging to the right degree.
Breakout rooms were very helpful to have pair conversations and introductions, so we could focus on our dialogue rather than just passively hear about it.

I preferred larger breakout rooms rather than one-on-one -- in these rooms you can't raise your hand to find the teacher like you would in a classroom, so I was often a little lost, and having more classmates helped

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 100% recommend this class to another student because though it is challenging and very work intensive you learn a lot in a short span of time.
I would recommend this course to another student. While there is a lot of work, I think it's a very interesting course and I learned a lot from it.

Yes! Especially if you are a heritage speaker, I know I would not have learned this much on my own through self studying, and it is special to be able to learn a native language that has died down throughout years of English schooling alongside people like you! It is an amazing community and much more fulfilling than any of my other classes because I know that this knowledge will just progress and be a part of my daily life with my family.
Yes, the professor teaches very well and with a smaller class size, it facilitates better learning and understanding.
Yes - I learned a lot of Chinese from a very low starting point

Yes!! If you are someone who wants to impress your Asian parents who have been nagging you about not knowing how to read or write in Chinese or are just wanting to expand your knowledge past basic listening and speaking this class is perfect for you! You will feel very cared for as a student and the projects/groupwork you do will also help you get to know your peers (as if the 4 times a week interactive sessions weren't enough to help you get to know your classmates haha)!
